summary: I looked through my TBR and realised that I have a lot of October releases there, in fact I have 9 books that are released in...
body:
I looked through my TBR and realised that I have a lot of October releases there, in fact I have 9 books that are released in October. Oh, the perils of being a book blogger!

Without further ado here’s my list of October releases I’m excited for –

October 2nd – 

Grim Lovelies – This book had me at ‘enchanted from animal to human girl’. Set in Paris this is Megan Shepherd’s debut and I can’t wait to get my hands on it.

Muse of Nightmares – I read Strange The Dreamer at the start of this year and have been anxiously awaiting the final book of the duology!

October 4th –

Dry – I got a sampler of this from YALC and it instantly went on by TBR. The taps run dry in a drought and chaos ensues.

Sawkill Girls – I love this cover! Scary stories, a ravenous evil and female power. I’m so up for this.

The Boneless Mercies  – Women are hired to kill quickly, and they hear of a monster slaughtering innocents. I hope this is as exciting as it sounds.

The Way Past Winter – A brother is stolen away and the sisters must travel North in a bid to save him. It sounds like a fairytale-esque book that I’ll adore.

October 9th – 

Beneath the Citadel – Ancient prophecies that came to pass, and a group of friends who uncover the mystery behind it. Sounds like the fantasy I always love.

18th October –

Distortion – Having read Ascension a few months ago and loving it (my review is here). I’ve been eagerly awaiting the next book, I want to know what happens!

October 23rd – 

Kingdom of Ash – This one doesn’t need any introduction. I’m excited and scared for this book.

There you have it. Some of the books that I’m excited for October release, I feel that for me it’s a good mix of genres, but monsters seem to be an over-arching theme. Perfect for these dark evenings!

I took a look through my TBR and picked out my most anticipated October releases. Featuring the likes of Sawkill Girls and The Way Past Winter October looks like it’ll be an exciting month! I looked through my TBR and realised that I have a lot of October releases there, in fact I have 9 books that are released in October.

tags: a court of thorns and roses
summary: Im glad I’m not alone in not wanting ACOTAR to become a movie.
body:
Im glad I’m not alone in not wanting ACOTAR to become a movie.

I honestly don’t think I’ll go see it. I might just avoid trailers, teasers and the whole dang feature of it.


After seeing the train wreck Twilight was and every other book to movie, I DO NOT TRUST HOLLYWOOD TO NOT SCREW THIS UP AND TAINT IT.


Twilight has become such a joke because of the movies, when some of the books were actually very enjoyable.


Uurggh, just leave it alone. 😫

title: Love Letter to Aspiring Artists
body:
To me the only difference between ‘great art’ and ‘ordinary art’ is that the ‘great art’ was loved by many people. You may feel your art is ‘bad’ or ‘not good enough’ but with practice you can become great. You don’t give yourself enough credit for the art you make. I appreciate your art no matter how messy, sketchy, or odd, it may look to you because, art is all about sharing ideas. Even if your sketch, drawing, painting, or anything else you create doesn’t look the way it does in your head you put in the effort. Usually, I can tell what you might have been thinking and fall in love with the idea and expression, not just what’s on the surface. Keep creating, keep expressing your ideas because, someday you could create something great to share with the world.

Love, 

            Shadows

tags: a court of thorns and roses
a court of mist and fury
a court of wings and ruin
body:
Story of my life

*bookstagram account posts a pic*

Me: I’m reading this next

*a publisher’s account posts a pic*

Me: Ooh I will definitely start this now

*friend suggests something*

Me: Next on my tbr, I swear!

Me: *stares at pile of unread books already in bookshelf* *stares at the three newly bought books*

Me: Shit. *Decides to reread SJM*

title: Drunk Book Tag
body:
Regitze fra Bookish Love Affair har tagget mig i dette vældig underholdende tag. Jeg må indrømme det ikke er et nemt tag at besvare, men sjovt var det. Hvis du læser dette og ønsker at lave tagget, så gør det endelig og link mig også gerne til svarene i en kommentar.

fanart, writing, music, film. Things that make us feel alive and
human. Things to pull us through, to believe in, to hold onto.

summary: A Court of Frost & Starlight by Sarah J. Maas "'I think my heart knew you were mine long before I ever realized it.'" Year Read:...
body:
A Court of Frost & Starlight by Sarah J. Maas

“‘I think my heart knew you were mine long before I ever realized it.’”

Year Read: 2018

Rating: 4/5

Context: I’ve seen almost nothing but negative reviews for this novella, and it’s pretty easy to see what happened. Fans were expecting a novel-quality plot to hold them over until the next book, and that’s one hundred percent not what this is. Much as I don’t like researching a book before I read it, it’s better to go into this one with eyes open. A Court of Frost & Starlight is a sweet, fluffy winter novella that shows the Night Court basically hanging out, preparing for a holiday, and managing their respective traumas from the previous series.

If you’re one of those people who could watch your favorite characters do laundry and be happy about it, this is for you. If you’re plot-driven, skip this one. I don’t feel that it’s a shameless money-grab (although the price is steep for so few pages– but then, it looks so lovely on the shelf with the others) so much as a labor of love, and that works better for some people than others. There are spoilers ahead for A Court of Thorns & Roses, A Court of Mist & Fury, and A Court of Wings and Ruin.

About: Solstice, a winter Christmas-like fae holiday, is approaching, and Feyre has no idea what to get for her family, particularly her difficult-to-shop-for mate. Worse, she’s not sure how she’s going to convince an isolated Nesta to join the festivities. Velaris and the rest of Prythian are still in a state of recovery after the war against Hybern, and that delicate peace could overbalance at any time. In between overseeing the Illyrian war camps and rebuilding efforts around the city, Feyre and the Night Court are preparing for the coming holiday and enjoying the fact that they’re all still alive to celebrate it together.

Thoughts: I don’t usually care much for “additional content” type-things like novellas/short stories, even though I’m compelled to read them anyway, so A Court of Frost & Starlight is a pleasant surprise. It’s true that it’s low on plot–the biggest conflict is whether or not Nesta will show up for Solstice dinner–but after the abundance of plot, war, and general trauma in the last three books, that’s almost a relief. This book is a snapshot image of what life might be like for the Night Court now that they’ve managed to survive. They have a chance at a happy life together, and I enjoyed seeing that play out. It reads a bit like fanfiction, in the way that fanfiction often focuses on characters and their interactions rather than What Happens, and I mean that as a compliment

There isn’t a lot of magic or world-building to be had here either. In part, it’s because Velaris as the main setting has already been established, and it’s also because the characters don’t need to defend themselves every few pages. Other than the occasional flying or Rhys and Feyre talking through their mating bond, they’re mostly preoccupied with very human problems like what to get each other for Solstice (a task I take very seriously, so I can relate). I half-wish I’d waited to read it closer to Christmas, since it has so much winter atmosphere. It will make the perfect fluffy holiday read.

There’s a lot of attention on how the Night Court characters are dealing with the trauma of surviving a war. It’s a little hilarious to see Rhysand, the most powerful High Lord in history, acting like a lovesick teenager who can’t keep it in his pants. Feyre wonders whether it’s right to spend time painting, which helps her healing process, when there are so many other things that need to be done for her city. Tamlin and Nesta isolate themselves from everyone, and Cassian tries to save the Illyrians from thousands of years of ingrained bigotry. There’s much less attention given to Azriel, Elain, and Morrigan (my queen). We’re never granted chapters from their perspectives, and if there’s one thing I would change about this novella, it’s that we’d have more time/development with them. Alas, there are only so many pages. While I doubt it will be necessary to read it to understand the next book, it does serve as a nice bridge to the coming novels and a bow on top of Feyre and Rhysand’s finished story.

Alas, there are only so many pages.
